description: GROUND FLOOR REAR EXTENSION TO PROVIDE 2x 1BED SELF-CONTAINED UNITS INVOLVING INTERNAL ALTERATIONS TO RETAIL UNIT AND SHOP FRONT ALTERATIONS; AND THE ERECTION OF A REAR ROOF DORMER.
decision_conditions: Reason : 1 - The proposed conversion would fail to offer a satisfactory outlook for the rear living area of Flat 2, and adequate usable external amenity area for the occupiers of Flat 1, to the detriment of the environment of future occupiers. This would be contrary to the London Plan (2016) Policy 3.5 and Merton Site's and Policies Plan (2014) Policy DM D2.

Reason : 2 - The proposed development would raise overlooking concerns to the occupiers of Flat 1 as the access route to Flat 2 would offer direct overlooking into the bedroom and living areas of Flat 1. This would be contrary to Merton Site's and Policies Plan (2014) Policy DM D2.

Reason : 3 - The proposal fails to demonstrate that policy compliant carbon dioxide reductions and water consumptions reductions can be achieved so as to make the fullest contribution to climate change mitigation and to ensure water usage in London is sustainable. The proposal would be contrary to London Plan 2016 Policy 5.2 and 5.15 and Policy CS 15 of Merton LDF Core Planning Strategy (2011).

Reason : 4 - INFORMATIVE
Note to Applicant
In accordance with paragraph 38 of the NPPF, The London Borough of Merton (LBM) takes a positive and proactive approach to development proposals focused on solutions. LBM works with applicants/agents in a positive and proactive manner by:
"	Offering a pre-application advice and duty desk service. 
"	Where possible, suggesting solutions to secure a successful outcome.
"	As appropriate, updating applicants/agents of any issues that may arise in the processing of their application.

In this instance:
"	The application was not considered to comply with the provisions of the Development Plan and NPPF as submitted, and would have required substantial changes such that a new application would be required. 
"	The application was considered to be fundamentally contrary to the provisions of the Development Plan and the NPPF, and there were not considered to be any solutions, other than to submit a new application, to resolve this conflict. 
"	It is noted that the applicant/agent did not engage in any pre-application discussions.
"	The applicant is advised to seek pre-application advice on any resubmission.
